image.altText: a man in a suit jacket and glasses

items.synopsis: Legal practitioners say a Palaszczuk government minister was obliged to report reprisal allegations raised in a one-on-one meeting with a whistleblower last year.

title.children: Reprisal allegations should have been reported after meeting with Queensland minister, legal expert says

image.altText: Drone aerial photo of empty inner-city bypass roads in Brisbane with RBWH in distance on May 1, 2020.

items.synopsis: Figures from Brisbane City Council have highlighted how fast motorists are travelling on the city's roads, with drivers hitting the brakes on some routes as others speed up.

title.children: Where Brisbane roads have got faster — and slower — since the pandemic

image.altText: A man in a suit sits at a desk with a microphone in front of an American flag.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump asked a staffer to delete camera footage at his Florida estate in an effort to obstruct the investigation into his possession of classified documents, according to an updated indictment.

title.children: Trump accused of asking staffer to delete camera footage in Florida classified documents case

image.altText: A composite of Tasmanian girl Shyanne-Lee Tatnell and police divers.

items.synopsis: A 36-year-old Scottsdale man accused of murdering Tasmanian teen Shyanne-Lee Tatnell after the discovery of bushland remains will be named when he appears in court this morning.

title.children: Man accused of murdering teen Shyanne-Lee Tatnell to appear in court

image.altText: Sam Kerr looks to her left as she watches the Matildas warm up for their World Cup match against Nigeria.

items.synopsis: The Matildas are still no closer to knowing whether Sam Kerr will be available to face Canada in their crucial final group match, as their World Cup campaign hangs in the balance following the loss to Nigeria.

title.children: Matildas on a knife-edge as they hope for Sam Kerr's World Cup return against Canada

image.altText: An overhead shot of university students sitting in a lecture theatre.

items.synopsis: Universities have told a Senate inquiry it is not "feasible" to attempt to detect AI cheats, instead saying the sector will have to overhaul its entire approach to teaching to ensure students actually learn what they are meant to.

title.children: Universities say AI cheats can't be beaten, moving away from attempts to block AI

image.altText: A woman with her arms folded stands against a tree.

items.synopsis: Documents show the Yarrabah Aboriginal Shire Council raised concerns with the state government over critical infrastructure failures more than a year before lead was discovered in the community's tap water.

title.children: Answers wanted over cause of lead leaching into drinking water

image.altText: Stuart Broad holds up his hands as David Warner looks behind him

items.synopsis: Australia wins the toss, sends England in to bat and wins the day, bowling them out for under 300 before negotiating the final session for the loss of just David Warner.

title.children: Australia's decision to bowl first in final Ashes Test pays off, although Warner's late wicket an unwelcome surprise

image.altText: A composite image of two Australian players looking determined, and one Nigerian player looking triumphant.

items.synopsis: Australia's loss to Nigeria sets up a must-win clash against Canada in Melbourne on Monday — these are the five things we learned from the day of play.

title.children: Five quick hits — Matildas face do-or-die clash against Canada as Australia fails to capitalise on early dominance

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green sits on her haunches after a game

items.synopsis: The Matildas dominated Nigeria in almost every category, but what does it matter when they lost the only one that counts, writes Sam Lewis.

title.children: Should the Matildas' loss to Nigeria be a reality check?

image.altText: Composite image of two women and a man.

items.synopsis: Awareness of the Voice is low among newly arrived migrant and refugee communities, a survey by settlement service AMES Australia finds.

title.children: 'This is their country': Migrants at a facility in Melbourne's south-east learning about Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A row of heavily armed men in camo gear, carrying guns

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin's attempted mutiny last month might have failed in Russia, but in Mali and a handful of other African nations, the Wagner Group's influence — and reign of terror — is expanding.

title.children: In a remote African town, armed men with Russian accents suddenly arrived. Putin's enemy sent them

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds up his ballot while voting in the election that makes him the prime minister

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will further escalate a high-stakes political stand-off with the Greens, in a move that could send Australians to an early, double-dissolution election.

title.children: PM stepping closer to early election trigger as housing battle with Greens escalates

image.altText: A old black and white photo of a soldier

items.synopsis: An auction house says the nieces of a man who was killed after destroying three Japanese machine gun posts in 1942 decided to sell his medal because there was a lot of responsibility in safeguarding it.

title.children: Victoria Cross could fetch more than $1 million as family offloads 'treasure'

image.altText: Aerial view of the Port Arthur historic site, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: A research paper finds World Heritage sites, protected for their unique natural or cultural values, are under extreme threat from climate change and risk being de-listed if those values are eroded.

title.children: 'Water is getting into these buildings': Sea level rises are hurting our World Heritage sites, research finds

image.altText: A graphic image shows the Metricon logo in front of a house

items.synopsis: More than 60 complaints have been lodged with NSW Fair Trading since March, with Metricon listed on the regulator's complaints register for the last four consecutive months.

title.children: Investigation launched into Australia's top home builder Metricon, as more complaints emerge

image.altText: Josh hazlewood, in Australian cricket gear, clenches his fists and cheers in celebration in front of the stumps.

items.synopsis: This fifth Ashes Test at The Oval is no dead rubber, as every subplot and story that has made this series great comes to a head with the history and future of the game seemingly on the line, Dean Bilton writes.

title.children: The Ashes may be settled, but the battle for the narrative is just getting started

image.altText: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in a blue collared shirt and Akubra hat, standing outside and looking down.

items.synopsis: A report from the Productivity Commission has exposed – without spelling it out – an odd shortcoming in the Albanese government's sales pitch for its Voice proposal, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: This week we saw an odd shortcoming in Albanese's sales pitch for the Voice

image.altText: Abbott gestures whilst talking wearing a black suit and dark blue tie on a committee bench inside parliament.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott claims the National Indigenous Australians Agency disburses $30b a year on Indigenous programs. Is that correct?

title.children: We fact checked Tony Abbott on his claim $30b is spent per year by the NIAA. Here's what we found

image.altText: Girl in silhouette watches sunset from rocks

items.synopsis: The United Nations secretary-general delivers a dramatic speech warning the heatwaves searing much of the northern hemisphere have been a "disaster" for the planet. An emerging El Niño means it may be just the start.

title.children: July set to be Earth's hottest month on record, with the UN warning the consequences are clear and tragic

image.altText: Dan Bell loooks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Dan Bell will never forget the day he had to help save the life of a colleague who'd been stabbed by a patient at Tasmania's North West Regional Hospital. It made him question his future as an emergency department nurse.

title.children: Dan has been punched, spat on and threatened while at work in the ED. He's desperate for change

image.altText: Sinead O'connor wearing a priests black outfit with a cross holding a microphone and smiling

items.synopsis: Police say singer Sinéad O'Connor was found unresponsive at an address in London and pronounced dead at the scene.

title.children: Sinéad O'Connor was found unresponsive at London address, police say death is not being treated as suspicious

image.altText: a woman smiles into the distance next to a cane field

items.synopsis: For a long time, the eldest son has been seen as the natural successor to a family farm. But there is change on the horizon.

title.children: 'Succession is a real life drama': Are the patriarchal tides turning for farm daughters?

image.altText: A girl sitting in a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Eileen's heart used to beat through her chest due to a rare medical condition. A lung transplant gave her a second chance, and her family would like to see more people register as organ donors.

title.children: In 12 hours, Eileen was taken from a Sydney hospital ward to Melbourne and had a new set of lungs

image.altText: An image of Sydney's CBD, with people walking, faces not visible, carrying shopping bags.

items.synopsis: The US economy has grown at a faster rate than economists predicted, warding off concerns it may fall into a recession this year, while Australian investors await retail sales data ahead of next week's RBA meeting. Follow live.

title.children: US economy fights off recession fears, local market set for weak start ahead of retail sales data

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It might be a Friday but that doesn't mean we don't have some economic data to look at — we're getting the latest retail trade figures for June at 11:30am AEST. These are pretty important figures, and are the final economic piece of puzzle before the RBA meets on Tuesday to determine what to do with the cash rate. In May, the retail trade figure was up by 0.7% compared to April, and rose by 4.2% compared to May 2022 (when rate hikes began). So why do we care about these figures? Because if the numbers are on the hotter side, it's going to spark discussion around what the RBA will do with rates. At the moment, markets are expecting a pause at Tuesday's meeting, but if there's been a solid amount of growth in retail spending, that could be enough to change their thinking. But given we've also seen stronger employment figures, to paraphrase CommSec market analyst Tom Piotrowski speaking to Thomas Oriti on ABC News Radio this morning, they could feed into better retail spending outcomes. And if that happens, he says that will probably weaken markets on the back of investors weighing up a higher likelihood of higher interest rates after next week .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up: Retail sales figures for June to be released

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New research from the e61 Institute is depressing reading but not a huge shock. The report finds that government contracting "disproportionately favours larger, politically connected firms" and that whatever the level of government of the sector the winners have certain things in common. "They’re old, they’re big, and they make major contributions to political parties." The new report Political Economy: The market for government contracts and influence reveals that over the last decade, the value of government contracts in Australia has more than quintupled, to $190 billion in 2022. The contracts are going to the already-big, according to e61 Institute. Nearly 80% of contracts were awarded to firms with over $100m in annual revenue in 2022, up from around 65% in 2014. The total contract value awarded to old firms (20+ years old) has climbed from around 45% in 2014 to 60% in 2022. In 2022, 75% of the value of government contracts went to firms that had won a contract in the previous year. Report author Dan Andrews (not the Victorian premier) says it's a problem because competition keeps prices down. "There are significant barriers preventing new, innovative firms from securing government contracts. Increasingly, it’s a few select firms to take on these major contracts, and stifling competition in the process." "Frequently these firms are the ones that have secured government contracts in the past. In fact, in 2022 75% of the value of government contracts went to firms that had won a contract in the previous year ." And for dominant firms — those in the top 10 by revenue — their dominance is being cemented. In 2014 those firms won over 35% of contract value in the professional services industry. By 2022 it was 40%. "New firms that secure government contracts are more likely to succeed, and thereby increase pressure on existing firms to improve their offerings. But what we’re seeing is a complete entrenchment of a few big players." Donation influence The report makes a further controversial point: that government contracts are increasingly going to firms that donate to major political parties. "Being      a political donor was associated with winning just under $1.5 million more      in contracts in 2014-15, while it was associated with around $11 million      more in contracts in 2021-22," the report states.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Big 'politically connected' firms get stronger as more government work flows their way: report

children.content: New research from the e61 Institute is depressing reading but not a huge shock.

The report finds that government contracting "disproportionately favours larger, politically connected firms" and that whatever the level of government of the sector the winners have certain things in common.
"They’re old, they’re big, and they make major contributions to political parties."
The new report
Political Economy: The market for government contracts and influence
reveals that over the last decade, the value of government contracts in Australia has more than quintupled, to
$190 billion in 2022
The contracts are going to the already-big, according to e61 Institute.
Nearly 80% of contracts were awarded to firms with over $100m in annual revenue in 2022, up from around 65% in 2014.
The total contract value awarded to old firms (20+ years old) has climbed from around 45% in 2014 to 60% in 2022.
In 2022, 75% of the value of government contracts went to firms that had won a contract in the previous year.
Report author Dan Andrews (not the Victorian premier) says it's a problem because competition keeps prices down.
"There are significant barriers preventing new, innovative firms from securing government contracts. Increasingly,
it’s a few select firms to take on these major contracts
, and stifling competition in the process."
"Frequently these firms are the ones that have secured government contracts in the past. In fact, in 2022
75% of the value of government contracts went to firms that had won a contract in the previous year

And for dominant firms — those in the top 10 by revenue — their dominance is being cemented. In 2014 those firms won over 35% of contract value in the professional services industry. By 2022 it was 40%.

"New firms that secure government contracts are more likely to succeed, and thereby increase pressure on existing firms to improve their offerings. But what we’re seeing is a complete entrenchment of a few big players."
Donation influence
The report makes a further controversial point: that government contracts are increasingly going to firms that donate to major political parties.

"Being      a political donor was associated with winning just under $1.5 million more      in contracts in 2014-15, while it was associated with around $11 million      more in contracts in 2021-22," the report states.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed this news last night, the Australian Financial Complaints Authority has seen a bumper 34% rise in the number of complaints it's received in the past 12 months. Australians have lodged 96,987 complaints with the financial ombudsman in the last year — the most complaints the ombudsman has ever recorded. The top five issues Australians complained about here: Delays in insurance claims (+76%) Unauthorised transactions (+69%) Service quality (-4%) Insurance claim amount (+42%) Denial of insurance claim due to exclusion/condition (+51%) AFCA's chief ombudsman David Locke said he was "deeply concerned" about the sheer volume of complaints made by Australians in the last financial year. "It's not fair on consumers and not good for business. We need to see a significant improvement from firms," he said. There was also a 46% increase in scam-related complaints to AFCA in the last financial year. Mr Locke also said there has been a link between the rise in complaints and the impact of financial stress due to rising interest rates and living costs. He said complaints rose significantly towards the end of the financial year — across April, May, and June — when the RBA increased its cash rate target to 4.1%. Financial difficulty complaints alone rose by 9% over the year, but were 31% higher compared to those same three months in the previous financial year (before the RBA began to lift rates). You can read the full story by my colleague Gareth Hutchens below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Financial complaints soar by 34pc as more Australians experience financial stress

featuredLink.title: Delays in insurer claims handling and financial scams drive record rise in complaints to financial ombudsman

children.content: If you missed this news last night, the
Australian Financial Complaints Authority has seen a bumper 34% rise in the number of complaints
it's received in the past 12 months.
Australians have lodged 96,987 complaints with the financial ombudsman in the last year —
the most complaints the ombudsman has ever recorded
The top five issues Australians complained about here:
Delays in insurance claims (+76%)
Unauthorised transactions (+69%)
Service quality (-4%)
Insurance claim amount (+42%)
Denial of insurance claim due to exclusion/condition (+51%)
AFCA's chief ombudsman David Locke said he was "deeply concerned" about the sheer volume of complaints made by Australians in the last financial year.
"It's not fair on consumers and not good for business. We need to see a significant improvement from firms," he said.
There was also a
46% increase in scam-related complaints
to AFCA in the last financial year.
Mr Locke also said there has been a
link between the rise in complaints and the impact of financial stress
due to rising interest rates and living costs.
He said
complaints rose significantly towards the end of the financial year
— across April, May, and June — when the RBA increased its cash rate target to 4.1%.
Financial difficulty complaints alone rose by 9% over the year, but
were 31% higher compared to those same three months in the previous financial year
(before the RBA began to lift rates).
You can read the full story by my colleague
Gareth Hutchens

image.altText: man holding large spider

items.synopsis: Australia Post is trying to stop online retailers from shipping live bugs across the country in the mail after researchers raised biosecurity and conservation concerns.

title.children: The most popular bugs sold online hint at a sub-culture that's now under threat

image.altText: Kyle Chalmers flexes his biceps in the pool after winning a race

items.synopsis: Kyle Chalmers and Kaylee McKeown add more gold to Australia's tally at the World Aquatics Championships, while the women's team in the 4x200m freestyle relay continues its record-breaking heroics.

title.children: Chalmers, McKeown win Fukuoka gold as Aussies set another relay world record

image.altText: A police officer looks down on a landslide that has caved in the side of a road on top of houses.

items.synopsis: Typhoon Doksuri regains super typhoon strength in its final approach to south-eastern China after pummelling Taiwan and the northern Philippines with rain and strong winds that led to the capsize of a ferry in which at least 21 people died.

title.children: Super typhoon heads towards China after ferry capsize kills at least 21 in Philippines

image.altText: Australian Financial Complaints authority ombudsman David Locke.

items.synopsis: The financial ombudsman has experienced a record rise in complaints as Australians voice their anger at scams, slow insurer claims handling, and buy-now-pay-later products.

title.children: Delays in insurer claims handling and financial scams drive record rise in complaints to financial ombudsman

image.altText: A woman in Islamic headscarf stands at a window with her back to the camera

items.synopsis: When Berivan was freed from ISIS captivity she faced a terrible choice: leave her homeland forever or abandon her daughter. Now she hopes Australia will come to the rescue, writes Stephanie March.

title.children: Berivan faced a terrible choice – to win her freedom she had to abandon her daughter

image.altText: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin talk.

items.synopsis: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken are here for meetings with their counterparts ahead of joint AUSMIN talks that are likely to feature climate change, regional geopolitics, AUKUS and expanding defence ties between Australia and the United States.

title.children: Two of the most powerful figures in US politics land in Brisbane for high-level talks

image.altText: Zainab shown from the side, her hijab is in view and she's looking at the shrines.

items.synopsis: Each year, millions of Shiite Muslims flock to Karbala in Iraq to mourn Imam Hussein. So what does Ashura mean to them?

title.children: 'Bringing people to tears shows how human they are': Why millions weep at this massive pilgrimage
